column4: so i swapped my mobo, and now i have no network devices.  i thought linux didn't care what hardware i had installed.
/etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net-rules
udev tracks NICs by MAC and will renumber devices.
que?
/sbin/ifconfig -a should list all known network devices.  If you see say, eth2, eth3, eth4, rather than starting w/ eth0, you've had devices renumbered.  Or you have a diffeent problem.
One sec.
I think you can just manually edit the file and renumber the high-numbered interfaces to 0, 1, etc.  Or delete the file and it's regenerated at boot when the udev scripts are run.
genii, i think you both hit the nail on the head.  there was an entry for eth0 w/my old via crap and a new entry for eth1.  i'm rebooting now.
Ok.  I think that reboot helps sort things out faster though it shouldn't be strictly necessary.
yea i just decided to blast out the file and reboot.  didn't feel like editing it, and the old entry didn't need to be there.
renaming is usually better than deleting.
true, i probably should've renamed the file.  but it's workin and i'm happy.  now to learn how to partition my 1tb hdd at the command prompt!
mv file file.bak or mv file file.$( date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S )
echo $( date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S ) to see what that does.
yes i know how to rename files.  i know that's what i should've done in case i needed to reinstate, but it's no biggie.
it's the date string substitution to create a timestamp for the backup fi.e
That's a datestamp in YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS format.  I find it useful for remembering *when* I created a particular backup file.
don't sweat it.  server's already rebooted, and i'm sshed into it now.
Yeah, just sharing the Wisdom.
ha, thanks.  i've been very careful about backing up configs to the "cloud" - just in case.
